articles.title: Scientists just found the hidden cosmic fingerprints of dark matter
articles.summary: Scientists at Rutgers and collaborators have traced the invisible dark matter scaffolding of the universe using over 100,000 Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies. By studying how these galaxies clustered across three eras shortly after the Big Bang, they mapped dark matter concentrations, uncovering cosmic “fingerprints” that reveal how galaxies grow and evolve.
articles.content:
A Rutgers-led team of scientists has uncovered evidence of how galaxies expand by tracing the invisible scaffolding of the universe created by a mysterious substance known as dark matter.

In a newly published study in Astrophysical Journal Letters, researchers used what they said are the largest-ever samples of special galaxies called Lyman-alpha emitters to study how galaxies clumped together over billions of years. In doing so, they gained an improved understanding of how galaxies relate to the surrounding dark matter and how they evolve over time.

"Analyzing these fingerprints gives us insight into the mass of dark matter surrounding the galaxies," said Eric Gawiser, a Distinguished Professor with the Department of Physics and Astronomy in the Rutgers School of Arts and Sciences and an author of the study. "The dark matter masses revealed by this study are consistent with the idea that Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies evolved into present-day galaxies like our own Milky Way."

The analysis, which assessed wide-field images across three different eras of the universe's history shortly after the Big Bang, revealed distinct patterns, akin to cosmic fingerprints. These patterns point to where dark matter is most concentrated, the researchers said.

Dark matter, a mysterious substance that doesn't emit light or energy, cannot be seen, but makes up most of the matter in the universe, according to scientists. They know dark matter exists because its gravity affects how galaxies move and how these vast cosmic systems are arranged in space.

The study, led by Rutgers doctoral student Dani Herrera, used data from the ODIN (One-hundred-square-degree DECam Imaging in Narrowbands) survey, which is a large astronomical project designed to analyze more than 100,000 Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies.

The researchers focused on data taken from a region of the sky known as the Cosmic Evolution Survey Deep Field (COSMOS), in one of the largest deep-sky surveys ever conducted. Looking deep into space and into the distant past, they viewed three time periods, some 2.8 billion, 2.1 billion and 1.4 billion years after the Big Bang. During these periods, Lyman-alpha emitter galaxies were young and actively forming stars, making them ideal markers for study. They also contain hydrogen gas that emits a special glow, which allows scientists to discover large numbers of them in the distant universe.

"We wanted to find the dark matter whose gravity drives galaxies to merge and grow," Herrera said. "Understanding where it is and how it has evolved helps us understand how the universe itself has evolved."

Dark matter plays a crucial role in galaxy formation by acting as a gravitational "glue" that helps pull gas together to form galaxies, Herrera said. Its invisible mass creates deep wells in space where galaxies can grow, merge and evolve, forming the large-scale structure of the universe.

"We used the clumpiness of these galaxies to identify where the dark matter was densest," Gawiser said. "Visualizing that with a contour map, much the way that a hiking map shows elevations, lets us observe the 'fingerprints' of dark matter in the distant universe."

One result stood out. Three percent to 7% of the dense regions of dark matter capable of hosting galaxies contain Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies, they found. This means that Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies represent a small percentage of the galaxies forming where the dark matter is densest. The low percentage hints that the galaxies were observed during a short-lived phase, glowing in Lyman-alpha light for tens to hundreds of millions of years.

To uncover these results, the researchers used a technique called clustering which measures how galaxies are grouped compared with random distributions. They calculated the angular correlation function, a method of counting pairs of galaxies.

This research, the scientists said, not only deepens understanding of galaxy evolution but also helps scientists refine models of the universe's structure. As the ODIN survey continues, future studies will expand to more galaxies, offering a more complete view of the cosmic web, they said.

"While invisible to our telescopes, dark matter shapes the universe through interactions with visible material," Gawiser said. "While some try to understand what it is, others like this research team try to understand where it is and what that implies about the evolution of the universe."

This discovery provides meaningful insights into the universe's structure and evolution, which has broad significance for the scientific community and humanity's understanding of the cosmos. The study is detailed, focused, and based on real data from a large astronomical survey, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news in space exploration and astrophysics.
articles.personality_title: Scientists map hidden dark matter using distant galaxies
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Dark matter is a mysterious substance that cannot be seen but makes up most of the matter in the universe. Scientists know it exists because its gravity affects how galaxies move and group together. Understanding dark matter helps explain how galaxies form and grow.

**What happened** – A team led by Rutgers University studied over 100,000 special galaxies called Lyman-alpha emitters. These galaxies shine brightly with hydrogen gas and lived shortly after the Big Bang, billions of years ago. Using data from a large sky survey named ODIN, the scientists mapped how these galaxies clustered in space. Their findings revealed patterns, or “fingerprints,” showing where dark matter is most concentrated.

**Impact** – This is the largest study of its kind, giving a clearer picture of the invisible dark matter that acts like a cosmic glue for galaxy formation. The research showed that only a small part of the densest dark matter regions contain these glowing galaxies, suggesting the galaxies shine in this way for a short time. This helps scientists understand how galaxies like our Milky Way have evolved.

**What’s next step** – The ODIN survey will continue to observe more galaxies to create an even more detailed map of the universe’s dark matter structure. This will improve models of how the universe’s large-scale structure formed and changed over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By studying distant glowing galaxies, scientists have traced the invisible dark matter that shapes the universe and drives galaxy growth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques cartographient la matière noire cachée grâce à des galaxies lointaines
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La matière noire est une substance mystérieuse invisible qui compose la majeure partie de la matière dans l’univers. Les scientifiques savent qu’elle existe car sa gravité influence le mouvement et le regroupement des galaxies. Comprendre la matière noire aide à expliquer comment les galaxies se forment et grandissent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par l’université Rutgers a étudié plus de 100 000 galaxies spéciales appelées émetteurs Lyman-alpha. Ces galaxies brillent grâce au gaz hydrogène et existaient peu après le Big Bang, il y a des milliards d’années. En utilisant les données d’une grande enquête astronomique appelée ODIN, les chercheurs ont cartographié comment ces galaxies se regroupaient dans l’espace. Ils ont découvert des motifs, ou « empreintes », montrant où la matière noire est la plus concentrée.

**Impact** – C’est la plus grande étude de ce type, offrant une image plus claire de la matière noire invisible qui agit comme une colle cosmique pour la formation des galaxies. La recherche a montré qu’une petite partie seulement des régions les plus denses de matière noire contient ces galaxies lumineuses, ce qui suggère que ces galaxies brillent ainsi pendant une courte période. Cela aide à comprendre comment des galaxies comme notre Voie lactée ont évolué.

**Prochaine étape** – L’enquête ODIN va continuer d’observer plus de galaxies pour créer une carte encore plus détaillée de la structure de la matière noire dans l’univers. Cela améliorera les modèles expliquant la formation et l’évolution à grande échelle de l’univers.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En étudiant des galaxies lointaines lumineuses, les scientifiques ont tracé la matière noire invisible qui façonne l’univers et stimule la croissance des galaxies.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos mapean la materia oscura oculta usando galaxias distantes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La materia oscura es una sustancia misteriosa que no se puede ver, pero que forma la mayor parte de la materia en el universo. Los científicos saben que existe porque su gravedad afecta cómo se mueven y agrupan las galaxias. Entender la materia oscura ayuda a explicar cómo se forman y crecen las galaxias.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por la Universidad Rutgers estudió más de 100,000 galaxias especiales llamadas emisoras de Lyman-alfa. Estas galaxias brillan con gas de hidrógeno y existieron poco después del Big Bang, hace miles de millones de años. Usando datos de una gran encuesta llamada ODIN, los científicos mapearon cómo se agrupaban estas galaxias en el espacio. Encontraron patrones, o “huellas”, que muestran dónde la materia oscura está más concentrada.

**Impacto** – Este es el estudio más grande de su tipo, que ofrece una imagen más clara de la materia oscura invisible que actúa como un pegamento cósmico para la formación de galaxias. La investigación mostró que solo una pequeña parte de las regiones más densas de materia oscura contiene estas galaxias brillantes, lo que sugiere que las galaxias brillan así durante un tiempo corto. Esto ayuda a entender cómo galaxias como la Vía Láctea han evolucionado.

**Próximo paso** – La encuesta ODIN continuará observando más galaxias para crear un mapa aún más detallado de la estructura de materia oscura en el universo. Esto mejorará los modelos sobre cómo se formó y cambió la estructura a gran escala del universo.

**Resumen en una frase** – Al estudiar galaxias distantes y brillantes, los científicos han rastreado la materia oscura invisible que da forma al universo y promueve el crecimiento de las galaxias.

articles.title: The Ancient Mars Variety Show
articles.summary: Written by Melissa Rice, Professor of Planetary Science at Western Washington University Perseverance accomplished something unusual this week: abrading two dramatically different rocks within the span of a few days. While exploring the Vernodden area along Jezero crater’s rim, the rover has been studying what might be “megablocks,” a variety of ancient crustal materials with […]
articles.content:
Image of the “Peachflya” abrasion spot, from Perseverance’s WATSON Camera on sol 1620. NASA/JPL-Caltech

Written by Melissa Rice, Professor of Planetary Science at Western Washington University

Perseverance accomplished something unusual this week: abrading two dramatically different rocks within the span of a few days. While exploring the Vernodden area along Jezero crater's rim, the rover has been studying what might be "megablocks," a variety of ancient crustal materials with clues to Mars' early geological history.

The target "Peachflya," abraded on sol 1618, revealed clasts of different mineral compositions. This could mean the rock is a breccia formed from fragments of even older materials that were broken up, transported, and cemented together – possibly during an impact in Mars' distant past.

Image of the “Klorne” abrasion spot, from Perseverance’s WATSON Camera on sol 1623. NASA/JPL-Caltech

Just meters away, the target "Klorne" was abraded on sol 1623 and it tells a completely different story. The fresh surface is greenish, with some dark spots and white veins—evidence of significant chemical alteration. Klorne’s green hue is consistent with the mineral serpentine, and reminiscent of Perseverance’s abrasion of “Serpentine Lake” back on sol 1404.

Next, Perseverance will examine the “Monacofjellet” megablock, which shows yet another distinct spectral signature. Each of these ancient fragments can help the Science Team reconstruct the complex geological processes that shaped early Mars billions of years ago.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific achievement by the Perseverance rover on Mars, revealing new insights into the planet's ancient geological history. This discovery has broad scientific importance for understanding Mars and the early solar system, offering tangible benefits to planetary science and humanity's knowledge of space.
articles.personality_title: Mars rover Perseverance studies two very different ancient rocks in days
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA's Perseverance rover is exploring Jezero crater on Mars. Scientists want to learn about the planet's ancient surface by studying big rock pieces called "megablocks," which hold clues to Mars' early history.

**What happened** – In just a few days, Perseverance used its tools to scrape off the surfaces of two very different rocks named "Peachflya" and "Klorne." Peachflya showed a mix of minerals suggesting it formed from broken pieces of older rocks stuck together, possibly after an ancient impact. Klorne had a greenish color with dark spots and white lines, showing chemical changes and containing a mineral called serpentine.

**Impact** – These two rocks tell different stories about Mars' past. Peachflya helps scientists understand how rocks were broken apart and moved long ago, while Klorne reveals chemical changes that happened later. Finding such variety close together helps researchers piece together how Mars' surface changed over billions of years.

**What's next step** – Perseverance will now study another megablock called "Monacofjellet," which looks different again. By examining these rocks one by one, scientists hope to build a clearer picture of the planet's early geological processes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Perseverance’s study of diverse ancient rocks in Jezero crater is uncovering new details about Mars’ complex geological history.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le rover Perseverance étudie deux roches anciennes très différentes en quelques jours
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le rover Perseverance de la NASA explore le cratère Jezero sur Mars. Les scientifiques cherchent à comprendre l'histoire ancienne de la planète en étudiant de gros blocs rocheux appelés « mégablocs », qui contiennent des indices sur le passé de Mars.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En quelques jours seulement, Perseverance a gratté la surface de deux roches très différentes nommées « Peachflya » et « Klorne ». Peachflya montre un mélange de minéraux suggérant qu'elle s'est formée à partir de morceaux de roches plus anciennes cimentés ensemble, probablement après un impact ancien. Klorne a une couleur verdâtre avec des taches sombres et des veines blanches, montrant des changements chimiques et contenant un minéral appelé serpentine.

**Impact** – Ces deux roches racontent des histoires différentes sur le passé de Mars. Peachflya aide à comprendre comment les roches ont été brisées et déplacées il y a longtemps, tandis que Klorne révèle des modifications chimiques plus récentes. Trouver une telle variété à proximité aide les chercheurs à reconstituer l'évolution de la surface martienne sur des milliards d'années.

articles.personality_title_es: El rover Perseverance estudia dos rocas antiguas muy diferentes en pocos días
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El rover Perseverance de la NASA explora el cráter Jezero en Marte. Los científicos quieren aprender sobre la antigua superficie del planeta estudiando grandes bloques de roca llamados "megabloques", que contienen pistas sobre la historia de Marte.

**Qué pasó** – En solo unos días, Perseverance raspó la superficie de dos rocas muy diferentes llamadas "Peachflya" y "Klorne." Peachflya mostró una mezcla de minerales que sugiere que se formó a partir de fragmentos de rocas más antiguas unidas, posiblemente después de un impacto antiguo. Klorne tenía un color verdoso con manchas oscuras y líneas blancas, mostrando cambios químicos y conteniendo un mineral llamado serpentina.

**Impacto** – Estas dos rocas cuentan historias diferentes sobre el pasado de Marte. Peachflya ayuda a entender cómo las rocas se rompieron y movieron hace mucho tiempo, mientras que Klorne revela cambios químicos que ocurrieron después. Encontrar tanta variedad cerca ayuda a los científicos a reconstruir cómo cambió la superficie de Marte durante miles de millones de años.

**Próximo paso** – Perseverance estudiará ahora otro megabloque llamado "Monacofjellet", que parece diferente. Al examinar estas rocas una por una, los científicos esperan formar una imagen más clara de los procesos geológicos antiguos del planeta.

**Resumen en una frase** – El estudio de Perseverance de rocas antiguas variadas en el cráter Jezero revela nuevos detalles sobre la compleja historia geológica de Marte.
